modules.title: Forensic Methodology
modules.content:
## Forensic Investigation Process

### Phases
1. Identification
2. Preservation
3. Collection
4. Examination
5. Analysis
6. Presentation

### Chain of Custody
- Document everything
- Secure storage
- Access logs

modules.title: File System Forensics
modules.content:
## File System Analysis

### NTFS Artifacts
- $MFT
- $LogFile
- $UsnJrnl

### Linux Artifacts
- /var/log
- .bash_history
- /etc/passwd

### Tools
```bash
fls -r image.dd
icat image.dd 1234 > recovered.txt
```

modules.title: Registry Forensics
modules.content:
## Windows Registry

### Key Hives
- SAM - User accounts
- SYSTEM - Configuration
- SOFTWARE - Applications
- NTUSER.DAT - User settings

### Analysis
```bash
# RegRipper
rip.pl -r SAM -p samparse

# Autopsy Registry Plugin
```

modules.title: Timeline Analysis
modules.content:
## Creating Timelines

### Data Sources
- File timestamps (MACB)
- Event logs
- Browser history
- Registry

### Tools
```bash
# Plaso/log2timeline
log2timeline.py timeline.plaso image.dd
psort.py -o l2tcsv timeline.plaso > timeline.csv
```

modules.title: Report Writing
modules.content:
## Forensic Reports

### Structure
1. Executive Summary
2. Objectives
3. Evidence
4. Analysis
5. Findings
6. Conclusions

### Best Practices
- Be objective
- Document methodology
- Include evidence
- Peer review

questions.question: Which NTFS file contains file records?
What is MACB in timeline analysis?
What is the first forensic phase?
Where is Linux command history stored?
